para.para.body: The coordinate vector of a vector \mathbf{x} in \RNr[n] is .... ?
A free floating arrow.
Sorry, no! - A free floating arrow ... this is how we think of a vector, not its coordinate vector.
This is a 4 -tuple
Yes! - This construct has 4 slots separated by commas. Therefore it is a 4-tuple
The n -tuple of numbers whose coordinates describe the location of the tip of a representing arrow in relation to the tail.
Yes! - This is correct!

Indeed, if \mathbf{x}=(x_1,\dots ,x_n) , then this tells us that, in order to get from the tail of a representing arrow to its tip, we need to go from the tail x_1 units in the first coordinate direction, from there x_2 units in the second coordinate direction, etc.
The n -tuple of numbers which describes the location of the tail of an arrow representing \mathbf{x} .
Sorry, no! - While it is true that the location of a point in \RNr[n] is determined by an n -tuple of numbers, the coordinate vector of a vector is a different concept.
Given the vector \mathbf{x} = (2,3,1) in \RNr[n] , how do you find the tip of the arrow representing x that has its tail at R(1,1,1) ?
add the coordinates of \mathbf{x} to the corresponding coordinates of R

By definition of the coordinate vector \mathbf{x} , we need to go 2 units from R in the first coordinate direction. So we arrive at the x -coordinate 3 . From there we need to go 3 units in the second coordinate direction. So we arrive at the y -coordinate 4 ; and from there we need to go 1 unit in the third coordinate direction. So we arrive at the z -coordinate 2 .
Combining these calculations, we find that the tip of the arrow is a S(3,4,2).
Subtract the coordinates of \mathbf{X} from the corresponding coordinates of R .

Sorry, no! - If you think you need to subtract the coordinates of \mathbf{x} from those of R , you need to review how exactly the coordinate vector x relates the tail of an arrow representing \mathbf{x} to its tip.
The tip of the arrow is at (1,1,1) .

Sorry, no! - This cannot be, for in this case the arrow would have its tail and its tip in the same location. However, the coordinate vector of \mathbf{x} tells us that we have to move off of R to get to the tip of the arrow in question.
Given the points R(2,–3,1,5) and S(3,1,–1,4) in \RNr[4] , how do you find the coordinate vector corresponding to the arrow with tail at R and tip at S ?
I add the coordinates of R to the corresponding coordinates of S .
Sorry, no! - You might be confusing the task at hand with the process of find the tip of an arrow whose tail is given, and whose associated coordinate vector is given.
Correct! - Indeed, this is the correct way to apply the formula
(tip coordinates) minus (tail coordinates).
Sorry, no! - You are partially on the right track, as you are taking a difference. However the correct formula is:
(tip coordinates) minus (tail coordinates).
